subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: scope of the chapter
subsection.p: Syntacticians of most persuasions would acknowledge a pre-theoretic distinction between ‘lexical’ (or ‘content’) words and ‘grammatical’ (or ‘function’) words in all languages. The conventionally accepted distinction between the two classes seems to be that the former allows novel coinages (open class), while the latter does not (closed class). Thus, while one can coin a new noun or verb, the number of pronouns, prepositions, and auxiliary verbs in a language remains relatively fixed, not open to coinages. Following this terminology, we can use the term ‘grammatical verb’ to refer to special closed classes of verbs that do not permit the addition of new members, except perhaps through the process of grammaticalization.

Grammatical verbs typically include auxiliaries, indicating meanings of relative time, perfectivity, or progression, and modal auxiliaries, indicating meanings such as those of obligation or permission (see chapter 70). They also include special verbs of possession (have) and existence (be), as well as the class of words often referred to as co-verbs, especially in the literature on East Asian languages.

In a large number of languages, grammatical verbs also include a special class of verbs called light verbs. The present chapter focuses on light verbs, specifically seeking to distinguish them from the other classes when empirical evidence is presented. For detailed discussions of the other subclasses of grammatical verbs, see modals (see chapter 70), the have/be distinction, causatives (see chapter 6), verb particle constructions (see chapter 76), the Chinese ba construction, the East Asian passive (see chapter 12), and serial verbs (see chapter 59).

Light verbs, which form a closed class, are limited in number, but are part of a construction that is extremely productive. The examples in (1b) and (1c) below illustrate a light verb construction in Malayalam, a South Indian language:

(1)
a. anu skuuLilninn
wannu.
Anu school-from came
‘Anu came from school.’
b. anuwin
santooSam wannu.
Anu-DAT happiness came
‘Anu became happy.’ (To Anu, happiness came.)
c. anuwin
aanayooT
deeSyam wannu.
Anu-DAT elephant-to anger came
‘Anu became angry with (toward) the elephant.’ (To Anu, anger came . . . )

The verb in all the sentences in (1) is wannu ‘came’. In (1a), this verb acts as a full verb. In (1b) and (1c), however, it is a light verb. It does not have the meaning of change of physical location associated with the verb come. Intuitively, the predicate in (1b) is santooSam wannu ‘became happy’, with a single argument, Anu. The predicate in (1c) is deeSyam wannu ‘became angry’, with two arguments, Anu and the elephant. The source of the difference in valency – that is, the number of arguments – is located in the nouns santooSam ‘happiness’ and deeSyam ‘anger’ respectively. In other words, the nouns ‘host’ the light verb, and bear part of the predicative burden. Together, they form a ‘complex predicate’ (Jespersen 1954–1958; Cattell 1984; Grimshaw and Mester 1988, among others), each incomplete as a predicate in isolation.

One may characterize a light verb as an independent grammatical verb that forms a complex predicate together with a host. This characterization obviously prompts the question of what a complex predicate is. A possible answer is that a complex predicate is a construction in which two morphs, both of which are semantically predicative, jointly head a single syntactic clause.

Stated at this level of generality, complex predicates manifest themselves in a wide range of constructions, not all of which necessarily involve a light verb. Thus, resultative constructions are analyzed as complex predicates, because they involve the combination of two predicates in a single clause (Simpson 1983; Levin and Rappaport Hovav 1995; Hale and Keyser 1997; Wunderlich 1997b). However, this construction does not have a light verb. Likewise, verbal affixes that in some way affect the valency, argument meaning, or case marking in a clause form complex predicates with their verbal host. (See Baker 1988a; Alsina 1996; Alsina et al. 1997; Ackerman and Webelhuth 1998.) However, these morphemes, though grammatical elements, are not light verbs, because they are not independent words. Other complex predicate constructions without light verbs include the verb + particle (see chapter 76) or verb + preposition structures.

A light verb, then, is a grammatical verb that functions as a member of a complex predicate construction. In this chapter, our concern is with complex predicate constructions that contain a light verb. This would exclude complex predicate constructions in which elements smaller than words, such as affixes, or constructions larger than words may serve the same semantic function as light verbs in some languages. To give an example, the applicative function – namely, that of adding an argument meaning, most commonly that of a beneficiary – is borne by a verbal affix in many languages (for instance, the Bantu languages, Indonesian, Malay, and Yimas: Foley 1997), or by special constructions, such as the dative construction in English. In yet other languages such as Malayalam and Mandarin, this function is fulfilled by a complex predicate with a light verb. Our concern is restricted to the last type.

It must be noted that Radford (1997: 264) defines a light verb as “an affixal verb (often with a causative sense, like that of make) to which a noun, adjective, or verb adjoins.” Under Radford's definition, a causative affix, an applicative affix, and in fact any verb-forming affix that involves an operation on argument structure or event structure would be a light verb. Such a definition stands in contrast to the one we assume in this chapter, namely, that a light verb is a word-level (X0) unit, and that while affixes in combination with nouns, adjectives, or verbs may form complex predicates, they are not light verbs.

subsection.heading: 2 ‘Light verb’ and its host
subsection.p: Original use of the term ‘light’ verb is due to Otto Jespersen, although the phenomenon was observed long before; Gilchrist (1796) called it a ‘subservient’ verb. Jespersen describes it as an insignificant verb which is placed next to an “important idea” to carry the markings of person, number, and tense (Jespersen 1954–1958: VI, 117–118).

Cattell (1984) lays out a range of relevant data on complex predicates from English, as well as issues surrounding their analysis. While complex predicates were variously explored under the guises of compound verbs, composite predicates, and serial verbs in a considerable amount of sporadic work over the years (discussions are found, for instance, in Ross 1986 (original dissertation 1967); Chomsky 1975b; Jackendoff 1972, 1974a; Higgins 1979 (original dissertation 1974); Oehrle 1976; Wierzbicka 1982), Cattell seems to have set the stage for the phenomenon of complex predicates to become a central preoccupation in most major syntactic theories, beginning with Grimshaw and Mester's (1988) analysis of the Japanese verb suru ‘do’. (See also Ackerman 1987; Baker 1988a; Sells 1988, 1991; Krishnamurti 1989; Miyagawa 1989a; Rosen 1989; Mahajan 1990; Huang 1992a; Mohanan 1994; Butt 1995, 1997; Alsina 1996; Matsumoto 1996a; Alsina et al. 1997; Cinque 1997a, 1997b; Ackerman and Webelhuth 1998; Wilson 1999.)

Let us use examples of the light verb construction in English to develop an intuitive sense of the phenomenon. The verbs in (2a), (3a), and (4a) are full verbs; their counterparts in (b) are light verbs:

row.entry: Pat made a dash across the puddle.
Pat took May to the park.

subsection.p: The light verbs in these examples have three characteristic properties. The first is that a light verb is identical in form to a heavy or full lexical verb in the language. Thus, each of the verbs in (b) in (2–4) has a counterpart that is not a light verb, as shown in (a).

Intimately related to this is the second property: that it is typical for the light verb not to have the entire meaning content associated with its full counterpart; it is often seen as an ‘incomplete predicate’ (Butt 1995; Alsina 1996). Part of the predicative burden is borne by its host, as in (1b) and (1c). Meshchaninov (1982: 158) describes the loss of meaning in the grammatical verb as follows: “Having become a linking verb, the verb loses one of its obligatory meanings – lexical meaning – and preserves another meaning – syntactic meaning.” A complete predicate “exists only in the union” of both meanings. The extent to which the core meaning of the verb is weakened or “bleached” (Masica 1976) in the light verb depends on the particular verb in each language. Perhaps an extreme instance of ‘lightness’ or semantic bleaching of a grammatical verb whose sole purpose is to bear the grammatical features of agreement and tense may be the so-called ‘dummy’ verb do in certain ‘do support’ constructions illustrated in (5) (see Grimshaw 1997b for a discussion):

(5)
a. Did Pat give Pip a toy?
b. Pat gave Pip a toy, and so did May.

The dummy verb do in these examples is often taken to be devoid of any semantic content, even though such a position is not unchallenged (Penhallurick 1985; Hewson 1990; Hirtle 1997; also see Kroch 1989b and Stein 1990 for a historical perspective).

The third property of light verbs such as those in (2–4) is that at some level of abstraction, the verb and the following noun seem to create a single predicate-like unit that is equivalent to a single verb. Thus, to take a bath and to give a gasp are equivalent to to bathe and to gasp respectively.

In (1–4), the host of the light verb is a noun. A light verb can also take an adjectival or verbal host. In languages like Hindi (a language of northern India) and Urdu (a language spoken in Pakistan and in northern India, almost identical in structure to Hindi) we find all three types of light verb constructions, illustrated by the examples from Hindi/Urdu in (6):

(6)
a. raam-ne niinaa-kii madad
kii.
(Noun + Verb)
Ram Nina's help did
‘Ram helped Nina.’
b. raam-ne kamraa saaf
kiyaa.
(Adj. + Verb)
Ram room clean did
‘Ram cleaned the room.’
c. raam has
paDaa.
(Verb + Verb)
Ram laugh fell down
‘Ram burst out laughing.’
The light verbs that take a verbal host, as in (6c), raise difficult analytical as well as theoretical problems, brought out by a comparison of different constructions involving V–V sequences:

(7)
a. raam-ne rootii khaaii.
Ram bread ate
‘Ram ate bread.’
b. raam-ne rootii khaaii
hai.
Ram bread ate is
‘Ram has eaten bread.’
c. raam rootii khaataa
hai.
Ram bread eats is
‘Ram eats bread.’
d. raam-ne rootii khaa
lii.
Ram bread eat took
‘Ram ate the bread (all of it).’
e. raam-ne rootii khaa
Daalii.
Ram bread eat put/flung
‘Ram ate up the bread (finished all of it, forcefully).’

A Hindi/Urdu grammarian would agree, perhaps reluctantly, that in (7b), the second verb in the verb–verb sequence might be treated as an ‘auxiliary’ that in combination with the first verb indicates perfective aspect; in (7c), it may be a ‘modal auxiliary’, expressing habitual action together with the first verb; and in (7e), it is a ‘light verb’, expressing completion and forcefulness. But we would be hard pressed to find a justification for these labels, at least on a cross-linguistic basis if not within Hindi/Urdu. Now, how about the second verb in (7d)? It may traditionally be considered a modal, indicating completion. However, Butt (1995) argues that it must be treated as a light verb, as it contributes to the argument structure of the complex predicate.

The analytical challenge posed by examples like (7a–e) are illustrative of problems raised by complex predicate constructions in general. How do we distinguish between light verbs and modal verbs? Is such a distinction between two types of grammatical verbs necessary? How do we distinguish between complex predicates on the one hand, and serial verbs (see chapter 59) and control constructions on the other? Are there clusters of cross-linguistic generalizations that converge on these distinctions? These are not easy questions to answer. In the rest of this chapter, we will point to partial answers when there is empirical evidence to make a principled distinction. (See Butt 1995 for an extended discussion.)

Perhaps one of the sources of the problem of a cross-linguistic characterization of light verbs is the multiplicity of intuitions associated with the term ‘light verb’, namely, that it is a verb that (i) has a full verb counterpart; (ii) can contribute to the argument structure of the clause; (iii) does not uniquely determine the argument structure of the complex predicate; (iv) permits a non-verb to function as a predicate; and (v) forms a single syntactic predicate with its host. Thus, be in John is asleep or The flower is red is a light verb by (iii), (iv), and (v) but not by (i) and (ii). The second verb in (7e) is a light verb by (i), (ii), (iii), and (v), but not by (iv). By (v), a verb that involves syntactic control cannot be a light verb. Switching between these intuitions often results in inconsistent conclusions.

In the following sections, we will first look at some of the central questions (section 3) of analysis and theory that the light verb phenomena give rise to. We then go on to a survey of light verbs that take a nominal host (section 4), a verbal host (section 5), and an adjectival host (section 6), and the lightest of light verbs, do (section 7), examining clusters of morphological, syntactic, and semantic properties of light verbs across languages that have intrigued syntactic theories, and some of the analyses that have emerged as a response to the phenomena. Our main concern will lie with the substance of the theoretical hypotheses that have emerged, some of which are consensual, and others still controversial. Their implementation within various syntactic frameworks is only of secondary interest.

subsection.heading: 3 Central questions that light verbs raise
subsection.p: There are three broad questions that studies of the light verb construction, whether language-particular or cross-linguistic, must pay attention to, so as to make possible the emergence of a theory of the light verb construction. They are:

li.p: What is a cross-linguistic characterization of complex predicate constructions such that they can be distinguished from other constructions involving auxiliaries, serial verbs, control/raising verbs, and (noun) incorporation?

Within the class of complex predicates, what are the similarities and differences between those that involve a light verb and those that don't? These include, on the one hand, complex predicates without an incomplete predicate, such as resultatives, and, on the other, those that involve affixation, such as morphological causatives.

subsection.p: Having addressed these questions, the next obvious question would be:
(iii) What are the parameters of variation among complex predicates, and what are the limits of variability?

On the basis of currently available studies, we can identify the following typological parameters of variation in terms of the various kinds of information that belong within grammar; in other words, different levels of representation within the organization of grammar. The terminology used in the formulation of the questions tries to be as framework-neutral as possible, and should be translatable into the different theories with the appropriate framework-internal vocabulary:

li.p: In terms of grammatical categories, do the light verb and its host form a single constituent? Is the host a lexical (X0) or a phrasal (Xbar) category? Is the light verb a lexical or phrasal category? Do the light verb and the host, when combined, form a lexical or phrasal category?

In terms of grammatical functions, do the light verb and its host form a single complex predicate? Or do they remain as two separate predicates, as in control or raising constructions? Does the host have an independent function?

As for the argument structure of the construction, does the light verb contribute to the valency and nature of the arguments of the complex predicate? Does the host contribute to this structure? Does the complex predicate have a single argument structure, or an embedded argument structure composed of main and subordinate argument structures?
How do the light verb and the host contribute to the other aspects of the syntactic behavior of the complex predicate, such as case marking and agreement?
What is the contribution of the light verb and the host to the meaning of the complex predicate? What is the relation between the meaning of the light verb and its full counterpart?
What are the meanings that typically lend themselves to light verb formation across languages?

subsection.p: A comprehensive theoretical account of the light verb construction must await the availability of detailed grammars that address these questions in individual languages, to ensure the coverage of all the attested patterns.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Complex predicates in English
subsection.p: The expression in boldface in (8a) is recognized in the literature, at least beginning with Chomsky (1975b), to be somehow different from that in (8b):

(8)
a. Pat made the claim that the snowman was innocent.
b. Pat disproved the claim that the snowman was innocent.

The complex expression made the claim in (8a) is perceived as a complex predicate; the expression disproved the claim is not. A number of syntactic and semantic properties distinguish the two constructions, justifying the claim that the expression in bold in (8a) is indeed a complex predicate, where a predicative noun combines with a light verb to form a single syntactic predicate.

To begin with, intuitively, make the claim is a single ‘semantic unit’ that is equivalent to the single verb claim. Thus, John made the claim that . . . is equivalent to John claimed that . . . In contrast, disprove the claim does not form a single semantic unit. This difference in semantics has correlates in syntax, for instance, in the contrast between (9a) and (9b):

(9)
a. ?Who did you make the claim that Bill saw ___?
b. *Who did you disprove the claim that Bill saw ___?

In order to account for what looks like a violation of the Complex NP Constraint in (9a), Chomsky (1975b) postulates a rule of restructuring which takes the structure in (10a) as the input, yielding (10b) as the reanalyzed structure, where make the claim is a single V:

(10)
a. [[make]V [the claim that S]NP]
b. [[make the claim]V [that S]S-bar]
In contrast, disprove the claim has only one structure:
(11) [[disprove]v [the claim that S]np]

If the representations relevant for Subjacency are (10b) and (11), the contrast between (9a) and (9b) would follow automatically. However, the reanalyzed structure in (10b) does not account for the contrast between (12a) and (12b):

(12)
a. That Bill defeated Pat John did not claim ___.
b. *That Bill defeated Pat John did not make the claim ___.

The ungrammaticality of (12b) must follow from the structure in (10a), which treats the claim that Bill defeated Pat as a noun phrase. Thus, to account for the contrast between (9a) and (9b), one must assume the availability of the structure in (10b). However, in order to account for the contrast between (12a) and (12b), one must assume that the structure is as in (10a), and that the structure in (10b) is not available.

The need for the two conflicting groupings in (10) illustrates the ‘dual’ nature of complex predicates. Now, these two structures cannot both belong to the same level of representation because that would constitute a logical contradiction.

One way to capture the intuition underlying the distinction between (10a) and (10b) is as in (13), where, in (13b), make the claim is a single unit in its function as a predicate (equivalent to (10b)), but its categorial structure is (13a) (identical to (10a)):

(13)
a. [[make]V [the claim that S]NP]
b. [[make the claim]PRED [that S]COMPL]

The structure relevant for relating a gap with its antecedent (governed by Subjacency or its equivalent) is the one in (13b), while the structure relevant for determining the position of the gap is the one in (13a).

The above discussion illustrates a recurrent characteristic of complex predicates with nominal hosts, namely, the mismatch between the structure in terms of grammatical categories and in terms of grammatical functions. The rest of section 4 outlines the central analytical and theoretical problems surrounding light verb constructions with nominal hosts.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Light verbs with nominal hosts in Hindi: a case study
subsection.p: In order to understand the phenomenon of light verbs with nominal hosts, and the theoretical questions they raise, it would be best to look closely at the construction in one language. As the language for illustration, we will use Hindi, where we find a duality of structure similar to that shown in English (section 4.1). Hindi offers a particularly fruitful starting point for exploring a cross-linguistic characterization of the complex predicate construction: it exhibits not only extremely productive complex predicate formation with nominal, verbal, as well as adjectival hosts (6a–e), but also a split among N+V complex predicates into two distinct types (Mohanan 1994, 1997).

Hindi has noun + verb sequences that are clear instances of constructions that are not complex predicates, as in (14). There are also instances of sequences that are uncontroversially complex predicates, as in (15). The verbs in (15) are the light counterparts of those in (14):

(14)
a. kal æksiDent huaa.
yesterday accident happened (M)
‘There was an accident yesterday.’ (An accident happened yesterday.)
b. raam-ne apnaa homwark kiyaa.
Ram-ERG self's homework did (M)
‘Ram did his homework.’
c. raam-ne niinaa-ko kitaab dii.
Ram-ERG Nina-DAT book gave (F)
‘Ram gave a book to Nina.’

(15)
a. kamre-kii safaaii
huii.
room-GEN cleaning happened (F)
‘The room got cleaned.’ (Cleaning of the room happened.)
b. raam-ne kamre-kii safaaii
kii.
Ram-ERG room-GEN cleaning did (F)
‘Ram cleaned the room.’ (Ram did cleaning of the room.)
c. raam-ne niinaa-kii kahaanii-par dhyaan
diyaa.
Ram-ERG Nina-GEN story-on attention gave (M)
‘Ram paid attention to Nina's story.’

In complex predicates like madad kar ‘help do’ in (6a), safaaii ho ‘cleaning happen’ in (15a), safaaii kar ‘cleaning do’ in (15b), and dhyaan de ‘attention give’ in (15c), the host noun (N) and the light verb (V), both predicative elements, combine to give a functionally single clausal nucleus. The N+V complex predicate construction in these examples exhibits certain clusters of properties that are recurrently found in the construction across languages, and can form an initial basis for a unified theory of complex predicates, including the parameters of variation available to the construction.

A striking trait of sentences with the N+V complex predicate in Hindi is that both the verb and the noun participate in determining the structure of the clause. Thus, in (15a) and (15b), the nominal host in the complex predicates is the same, but the verb is different. (15a) has one argument, (15b) has two. This difference in valency must therefore be contributed by the light verb. As for the contribution of the noun, the data involving the light verb aa ‘come’ provide a telling example. This verb in its capacity as a full verb has two arguments, as shown by (16): the entity that comes, and its locative destination:

(16)
raam mere ghar aayaa.
Ram my house came
‘Ram came to my house.’
In (17), the same verb ‘come’ functions as a light verb:

(17)
a. mohan-ko hasii
aayii.
Mohan-DAT laughter came
‘Mohan had the urge to laugh.’ (Laughter came to Mohan.)
b. mohan-ko kahaanii yaad
aayii.
Mohan-DAT story memory came
‘Mohan remembered the story.’ (Memory of the story came to Mohan.)
c. mohan-ko anu-kaa dhyaan
aayaa.
Mohan-DAT Anu's attention came
‘Mohan thought of Anu.’ (Thought of Anu came to Mohan.)
d. mohan-ko anu-par krodh
aayaa.
Mohan-DAT Anu-on anger came
‘Mohan was angry with Anu.’ (Anger on Anu came to Mohan.)

In (17a), there are two arguments: the entity that comes, laughter, and its destination, Mohan. But the destination is an abstract one; it is an experiencer. In addition to the destination being an experiencer, the sentences in (17b–d) have an extra argument, not sanctioned by the verb aa ‘come’. This argument must therefore be sanctioned by the noun. Furthermore, the case marking of the additional argument can differ depending on the noun: in (17b) it is nominative, in (17c) genitive, and in (17d) locative. (The case differences exhibited in (17b–d) on non-subjects can also appear on subjects: Mohanan 1997: 436). If we assume that differences in non-structural case marking indicate differences in argument meaning, then the meanings of the additional arguments in these sentences must also be different.

In short, the nominal host in a complex predicate can contribute to the number of arguments, their meaning, and the case assigned to them, and so can the light verb. This property of the complex predicate in Hindi is demonstrable in other languages of South Asia as well. We can state our observations so far as (18):

(18) In the N+V complex predicate, the N and V together act as a single predicate. However, both the N and the V are predicates in their own right: they can contribute to the number of arguments, argument meanings, and case marking in the clause.

Evidence from the behavior of reflexives, which at least in some varieties of Hindi take either the grammatical subject or the logical subject as their antecedent, shows that functionally, the complex predicate is a single clausal nucleus (Mohanan 1997: 443–444). Categorially, however, the N and V are concatenated phrasally, as shown by the topicalizability of the light verb (Mohanan 1997: 447–448). We can state this mismatch as follows:
(19) Functionally, the N and V form a single predicate; however, they are phrasally combined: they do not have a lexical status.

Even though the nominal host is part of the predicate, and a predicate in its own right, it is also an argument of the light verb in Hindi. This is shown by the fact that the nominal host can be the subject of a passive. Furthermore, the light verb exhibits agreement with its host in number, gender, and person; verb agreement in Hindi can only be induced by a subject or an object in nominative case. This leads to our next conclusion:
(20) Although the N is a predicate, and part of the complex predicate, it is, in some cases, also simultaneously an argument of the V.

In terms of the property in (20), the N+V complex predicates in Hindi appear to split into two classes. There is a small group of nominal hosts that are different from the rest in certain syntactic patterns. A nominal host belonging to this class cannot trigger verb agreement; it cannot be the subject of a passive; a negative word indicating syntactic negation can precede it; and it can gap and be gapped in a coordinate construction. All these differences follow naturally if we assume that the host in these instances is not an argument of the light verb.

The structural properties in (18–20) present a challenge. How must the compositionality of complex predicates be formally expressed such that the semantic and syntactic representation of the light verb and its host, together with the structural relation between the two, derives the semantic and syntactic properties of the complex predicate? What kind of syntactic and semantic theory can describe this compositionality? While framework-internal analyses of different aspects of different types of complex predicates are available, covering rich data with recurrent clustering of properties, answering the above questions requires bringing together all of the fragments into a comprehensive picture. We do not as yet have such an integrated theory of complex predicates.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Complex predicates, noun incorporation, and raising/control
subsection.p: As mentioned earlier, the light verb construction rose into prominence in theoretical syntax with the study of the Japanese light verb suru ‘do’ in Grimshaw and Mester (1988) (G&M). The central problem that G&M address is illustrated by the Japanese construction in (21a), and its behavioral contrast to (21b):

(21)
a. John-wa Bill-to AISEKI-o shita.
John-Top Bill-with table-sharing-Acc suru-past
‘John shared a table with Bill.’
b. John-wa Bill-to AISEKI shita.
John-Top Bill-with table-sharing suru-past
‘John shared a table with Bill.’ (G&M: 206)

In both (21a) and (21b), the verb suru ‘do’ appears to form a single unit with the preceding noun at some level of grammatical structure. The overt difference between them is that while the preceding noun in (21a) carries accusative case marking, that in (21b) is a bare noun. G&M claim that while (21a) is an example of a complex predicate construction with suru as a light verb, (21b) is an example of the noun incorporation construction.

Subsequent literature (Ahn 1990; Huang 1992a; Matsumoto 1996a, 1996b; among others), however, disputes the claim that suru in (21a) is a light verb, and argues that (21a) is not an example of a complex predicate construction, but rather a raising/control construction involving a main verb and a complement clause. Yet other works accept that suru in (21a) is a light verb, but reject the G&M claim that it is an empty verb without its own argument structure. (For a detailed discussion of the issues and analyses related to suru, see Butt 1995: 201–221.)

In order to get a clear understanding of the issues involved in the different constructions, therefore, it would be productive to explore what properties constitute the necessary conditions for a construction to be called complex predicate (CP) or noun incorporation (NI), and how they are both different from raising/control constructions. One way to identify the parameters along which the differences can be characterized is in terms of the categorial and functional properties of the N+V sequences. The first distinction to recognize is that CP and NI constructions involve a single syntactic clause, while raising/control involve a matrix clause and an embedded clause.

Within the single-clause constructions, the relevant parameters include the categorial status of the nominal host (N), the light verb (V), and the complex predicate ([N, V]), and the functional status of the nominal host. A possible way to distinguish the two constructions is as follows:

(22)
NI
CP
Categorial status a. of N Lexical Lexical or phrasal
b. of V Lexical Lexical or phrasal
c. of [N, V] Lexical Lexical or phrasal

(23)
NI
CP
Functional status of N a. as argument Yes Maybe
b. as predicate No Yes
Whether the specifications in (22) and (23) should be accepted as criterial of CP and NI constructions is for future research to determine.

The parameters in (22) and (23) point to possible cross-linguistic variability in N+V complex predicates. One parameter of variation is the argumenthood of the nominal host (23a). As indicated earlier, Hindi itself distinguishes two classes, one in which the host is a syntactic argument, and another in which it is part of the predicate without any argument status. Another parameter of variation is the categorial level of the host (22a). In Hindi, it is a lexical category. In a language like Malayalam, in contrast, the host is a phrasal category (Mohanan 1983). Such typological variations deserve careful study.

Other variations in N+V complex predicates appear in languages like Korean (Ahn 1990; Sells and Cho 1991). The host noun, a lexical category, participates in three types of complex predicates, each displaying a different cluster of syntactic properties. One is lexically concatenated, and is syntactically unanalyzable; it obeys the lexical integrity principle (Ackerman 1987; Di Sciullo and Williams 1987; Simpson 1991; Sells 1994; Bresnan and Mchombo 1995; Mohanan 1995), which prohibits subconstituents of a lexical unit from undergoing syntactic reordering; examples are kwen-hata ‘encourage’ and ceng-hata ‘decide’. The second and third types are phrasally concatenated: adverbs and negatives can intervene between the N and V. The phrasally combined complex predicates fall into two classes in terms of their behavior with respect to replies to yes/no questions, gapping, and the ability to take accusative marking. The two classes are distinguished by the fact that in contrast to the nominal hosts in examples like phantan hata ‘judge’ and sayngkak hata ‘think’, those in examples like yenkwu hata ‘research’ and kongpwu hata ‘study’ can be omitted in the reply to a yes/no question, can be gapped independently of the light verb, and can take the accusative marking (l)ul.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Causative light verbs
subsection.p: We now turn to the light verbs that combine with verbal hosts. Consider the English examples in (24), where (24b) is a causative (see chapter 4) version of (24a):

(24)
a. Pat combed Ellen's hair.
b. Pat made Jan comb Ellen's hair.

(24b) is an example of a syntactically biclausal causative. If the object Ellen in (24b) is replaced with the pronoun him, the pronoun can take Pat as its antecedent. On the other hand, if we replace it with the reflexive himself, the reflexive cannot take Pat as its antecedent. These facts follow from the conditions of disjoint reference and reflexive binding (Binding Conditions B and A respectively in GB/Minimalist syntax), given that make and comb belong to different clauses in (24b).
Now consider the German sentence in (25a), and its causative versions in (25b, c):

(25)
a. Ellen hat den Jungen gekämmen
Ellen has the boy combed
‘Ellen combed the boy.’ (Ackerman and Webelhuth 1998: 275)
b. Ellen ließ den Vater den Jungen kämmen.
Ellen cause the father the boy comb
‘Ellen made the father comb the boy.’ (Ackerman and Webelhuth 1998: 279)
c. Ellen ließ den Jungen von seiner Schwester kämmen
Ellen cause the boy by his sister comb
‘Ellen had the boy combed by his sister.’ (Ackerman and Webelhuth 1998: 275)

Ackerman and Webelhuth (1998) argue that (25b) behaves like a bi-clausal structure, exactly like the English example in (24b). However, the behavior of (25c) leads them to conclude that the sentence is monoclausal. Given that the verb ließ in (25c), which is an independent verb (not an affix), forms a single syntactic predicate with the following verb and contributes to the argument structure of the clause, it follows from our earlier characterization that ließ is a light verb in (25c), and that ließ . . . kämmen is an example of a complex predicate. In contrast, the sentence in (25b) is an example of a bi-clausal raising/control construction, and ließ is not a light verb.

Additional evidence from disjoint reference also points to the conclusion that (25c) is monoclausal, while (25b) is bi-clausal. Thus, if ‘the boy’ in (25b) is replaced with the pronoun ihn, the pronoun can take as its antecedent the subject Ellen (Miriam Butt, p.c.). But if ‘his sister’ in (25c) is replaced by the pronoun, it cannot take Ellen as its antecedent. Together with the rest of the evidence, then, disjoint reference shows that (25c) has a single syntactic clause. This situation illustrates the possibility, even within a single language, of an analytical causative being either a complex predicate construction with a light verb as in (25c), or a raising/control causative such as that in (24b) and (25b).

In the following sections, we will take a closer look at some more light verbs that take verbal hosts. We will see that the issues related to the analysis of N+V complex predicates discussed earlier resurface in a slightly different guise in the analysis of V+V complex predicates.

subsection.heading: 5.2.1 ‘Give’ compounding
subsection.p: The phenomenon of applicatives has generally been viewed as one in which an indirect object, oblique object, or non-argument appears as an object of the clause (henceforth ‘applied object’). The dative construction in English, illustrated in (26b) below, can be understood as a restricted version of the phenomenon of applicatives:

(26)
a. Miko sang a song for Jomo.
b. Miko sang Jomo a song.

Languages vary with respect to the theta-role of the applied object; a particular language may allow one or more of the following: beneficiaries, goals, instruments, locatives (Baker 1988a; Bresnan and Moshi 1990; Alsina and Mchombo 1993; Foley 1997). In languages with restricted instances of the applicative, including English, the applied object is typically a beneficiary.

As mentioned earlier, the applicative complex predicate may involve a light verb in some languages, for instance Malayalam. (Note that in the applicative in English, the verb bears no overt verbal marking.) The applicative in Malayalam has been described as give-compounding (Mohanan 1983, 1989), because it involves a V+V predicate in which the second V is the word for ‘give’. (See Wong 1995 for a construction with similar effects in Mandarin involving the verb gei ‘give’.)
Consider the triadic verb koTukk- ‘give’ in (27):

(27)
uma ammuwin
oru pustakam koTuttu.
Uma Ammu-DAT one book gave
‘Uma gave a book to Ammu.’
Applicatives in Malayalam are formed through a productive V+V compounding, where the second V is koTukk- ‘give’, as illustrated in (28b):

(28)
a. uma oru paaTT
paaTi.
Uma one song sang
‘Uma sang a song.’
b. uma baalan
oru paaTT
paaTi koTuttu.
Uma Balan-DAT one song sang gave
‘Uma sang Balan a song.’
c. *uma baalan
oru paaTT
paaTi.
Uma Balan-DAT one song sang
d. uma baalan
-weeNTi oru paaTT
paaTi.
Uma Balan-DAT-for one song sang
‘Uma sang a song for Balan.’
e. *uma oru paaTT
paaTi baalan
koTuttu.
Uma one song sang Balan-DAT gave
Intended: #’Uma sang a song and gave it to Balan.’

The verb ‘sing’ in (28) is dyadic. In (28b), where it occurs with ‘give’ in a V+V compound, ‘give’ contributes to the clause an additional beneficiary argument. An even more telling example of such argument addition is given in (29):

(29)
a. ani aLaweTukkaan ninnu.
Ani measurement-take-INF stood
‘Ani stood for the purpose of having her measurements taken.’
b. ani ammuwin
aLaweTukkaan ninnu koTuttu.
Ani Ammu-DAT measurement-take-INF stood gave
‘Anu stood for Ammu to take her measurements (for Ammu's benefit).’
c. *ani ammuwin
aLaweTukkaan ninnu
Ani Ammu-DAT measurement-take-INF stood

On the basis of (28) and (29), one might be tempted to treat the syntactic effect of this compounding as one of increasing valency. However, as (30) shows, even though it involves the additional meaning of a beneficiary, it is not necessary that give-compounding always adds an argument to the clause:

(30)
a. uma aniye kuukkaan paThippiccu.
Uma Ani-ACC shout-INF taught
‘Uma taught Ani to shout.’
b. uma anik’k’
kuukkaan paThippiccu koTuttu.
Uma Ani-DAT shout-INF taught gave
‘Uma taught Ani to shout.’
c. *uma anik’k’
kuukkaan paThippiccu
Uma Ani-DAT shout-INF taught
d. *uma aniye kuukkaan paThippiccu koTuttu.
Uma Ani-ACC shout-INF taught gave

The object of ‘teach’ in (30a) is in the accusative case. Its counterpart in (30b), where the predicate is a give-compound, is in the dative case. Also, (30b) has the added meaning that the teaching was either desired by or beneficial to the learner. (30a) carries no such implication. In other words, the second argument in (30a) is a ‘theme’, while that in (30b) is both a theme and a beneficiary. There is no additional argument in (30b).

What we have here is a complex predicate construction in which the verb ‘give’ functions as a light verb. It adds the meaning of beneficiary to the clause, which may or may not result in the addition of an independent beneficiary argument. It also requires the beneficiary to be in the dative case. The benefit in this construction is the entire event described by the host of the light verb. Thus, in (28b), Uma is the agent, Balan is the beneficiary, and the event of Uma's singing a song is the theme that benefits Balan.

If the argument meanings of the full verb koTukk- ‘give’ in (27) are compared with those of the light verb in (28b), (29b), and (30b), an interesting difference appears. The dative argument in (27) is a recipient who is not necessarily a beneficiary. Thus, we can add ravik’k’
weeNDi ‘for Ravi’ to (27), to mean ‘Uma gave a book to Ammu for Ravi.’ In other words, a beneficiary can be added to the sentence as an adjunct. In contrast, such a beneficiary adjunct cannot be added to a complex predicate construction with the light verb koTukk-. This suggests that the dative argument of the complex predicate V-koTukk- is a beneficiary, not merely a recipient.

Furthermore, the dative argument of the full verb can be the recipient of an undesirable theme. For instance, a sentence in which pustakam ‘book’ in (27) is replaced by wiSam ‘poison’, which is harmful to the recipient, is entirely acceptable. In contrast, the event that is of benefit to the dative argument in the light verb construction cannot be undesirable to the beneficiary. Thus, in a context in which Balan dislikes Uma's singing, the sentence in (28b) is unacceptable.

In sum, the special characteristics of the light verb ‘give’ in Malayalam can best be understood as a grammaticalization of the full verb ‘give’. (31) below gives the parallel properties that bring out the effects of grammaticalization:

(31)
Property
Full verb
Light verb
a. number of arguments: three √ √
b. Argument meanings:
(i) Agent √ √
(ii) Recipient √ Desirable benefit
(iii) Theme √ √
c. Theme:
(i) Concrete entity √ No
(ii) Event No √
d. Transfer from agent to recipient √ No
e. Case of recipient/beneficiary: dative √ √

The difference between the full verb and the light verb lies in their semantics: (i) the dative argument of the light verb is a beneficiary, (ii) the theme is an event, not an entity, and (iii) no transfer is involved.

It must be pointed out that the verb ‘give’ appears recurrently across languages as the indicator of the applicative meaning. Some examples are given below. Each of the examples appears to be an applicative with a light verb ‘give’:

(32)
mama féng-gèí
Xiàóqí yì tiáo qúnzi. Mandarin
mother sew-give Xiaoqi one CL skirt
‘Mother sewed Xiaoqi a a skirt.’ (Wong 1995: 12)

(33)
i e prani a karu gi
yu. Sranan
I plant the corn give you
‘I'm planting the corn for you.’ (Sebba 1987: 50)

(34)
a séi dì wòsu dà
dì wòmi. Saramaccan
he sell the house give the man
‘He sold the house for the man.’ or ‘He sold the house to the man.’
(Byrne 1987: 177)

(35)
nws xa ib qho khoom pub
kuv. White Hmong
3sg send one class. goods give 2sg
‘She sent me some things (as a present).’ (Jarkey 1991: 244)

Heine and Reh (1983) observe that the applicative morpheme in a number of African languages developed historically from the verb for ‘give’. Ahn (1990) and Matsumoto (1996b) argue that the apparently parallel construction in Japanese and Korean involving the verbs for giving and receiving are not complex predicate constructions; rather, they are constructions involving a main verb and a complement clause. Given our characterization of light verb as part of a complex predicate, we must conclude that the verbs ‘give’ and ‘receive’ in this construction in Japanese and Korean are not light verbs. However, given that these constructions resemble those of the applicative light verb constructions, an alternative view of light verbs would be to delink their characterization from complex predicatehood, and define them as grammaticalized, bleached verbs that have a ‘full’ counterpart, whether or not they are part of a complex predicate. The wisdom of such a recharacterization of light verbs cannot be assessed without further investigation.

subsection.heading: 5.2.2 ‘Get’ compounding
subsection.p: Another light verb construction which involves the addition of a beneficiary meaning is what may be called get-compounding. The Malayalam example in (36) is a simple sentence with the verb kiTT- ‘get’ as a full verb:

(36)
anuwin
looTTari kiTTi.
Anu-DAT lottery got
‘Anu won a lottery. (Anu got a lottery.)’
The verb kiTT- ‘get’ participates as a light verb in a complex predicate construction. Compare the give-compounding version of (37a) in (37b) with its get-compounding version in (37c):

(37)
a. anu oru keikk
uNTaakki.
Anu one cake made
‘Anu baked a cake. (Anu made a cake.)’
b. uma anuwin
oru keikk
uNTaakki koTuttu.
Uma Anu-DAT one cake made gave
‘Uma made Anu a cake.’
c. anuwin
oru keikk
uNTaakki kiTTi.
Anu-DAT one cake made got
‘Anu got the benefit of someone baking a cake.’
In the example of get-compounding in (37c), Anu is the beneficiary of the theme, namely, the event of baking a cake.
Consider another example of get-compounding in (38b):

(38)
a. kuTTi skuuLil etti.
child school-in arrived
‘The child arrived in school.’
b. ammak’k’
kuTTi skuuLil etti kiTTi.
mother-DAT child school-in arrived got
‘The mother received the benefit of the child arriving in school.’

Give-compounding requires an agent and a beneficiary; if the host does not have a beneficiary, the light verb supplies one, either as an argument or as an argument meaning. However, if the host does not have an agent, the light verb cannot combine with it. Thus, a give-compounding version of (38a) is not possible to create, because (38a) does not have an agent to begin with.

Like give-compounding, get-compounding requires a beneficiary, and the light verb adds it if one is not already available. The beneficiary in (37c) and (38b) is not an argument of the verbal host; it is contributed solely by the light verb. In contrast to ‘give’, however, the light verb ‘get’ does not permit the expression of the agent. Thus, the agent of the host in (37c) is unexpressed; expressing the agent of ‘make’ in any form would render the sentence unacceptable.
A comparison of the main verb kiTT- ‘get’ and its light counterpart shows the following differences:

(39)
Property
Full verb
Light verb
a. Number of arguments: two √ √
b. Argument meanings:
(i) Recipient √ Beneficiary
(ii) Theme √ √
c. Theme:
(i) Concrete entity √ No
(ii) Event No √
d. Transfer to recipient √ No
e. Case of recipient/beneficiary: dative √ √
f. Agent cannot be an argument √ √

The properties of get-compounding, then, are that (i) the complex predicate has two arguments; (ii) the logical subject is a beneficiary, not just a recipient; and (iii) the theme is an event, not an entity. The two complex predicate constructions, ‘give’-applicative and ‘get’-applicative, are parallel in that they both add a beneficiary meaning to the clause, where the benefit is an event; they differ in that the former requires an agent, while the latter prohibits one. This difference follows naturally from the argument structures of the full verbs.

The discussion of give-compounding and get-compounding in Malayalam shows that the idea of deriving the light verb through semantic bleaching of the full verb is not viable if bleaching is interpreted as implying the strong claim stated in (40):
(40) The semantic structure of the light verb is a proper substructure of the semantic structure of the full verb.

The light verbs koTukk- ‘give’ and kiTT- ‘get’, unlike their full counterparts, require that their dative argument be the beneficiary of a desirable outcome. In other words, they impose a semantic condition not found in the full verb. Hence, (40) could not be correct.

The general characteristics illustrated by the behavior of the applicative light verbs in Malayalam can now be summarized as follows. A light verb may impose a requirement on an argument of the complex predicate; if the host does not satisfy this requirement, the light verb may either contribute an additional argument (addition) or add the required argument meaning to an existing argument (merging). A light verb may also impose a requirement that results in suppressing a semantic role of the host, thus preventing it from being expressed as an argument (suppression). Finally, it may require its host to contain a specific argument, as in the case of an agent in give-compounding. These properties support the conclusion that it is necessary to factor apart the semantic information and the valency information conflated in theta-role labels like agent, recipient, beneficiary, and theme.

subsection.heading: 5.3 Aspectual and modal light verbs in Hindi/Urdu
subsection.p: Complex predicates of the form V+V are so prevalent in the South Asian languages that a detailed description of their meanings has long been a central preoccupation of grammarians of these languages. Masica (1976) lists the varied and manifold meanings that light verbs bring to the complex predicate: they connote “completion, suddenness, directionality, benefaction, intensity, violence, stubbornness, reluctance, regret, forethought, thoroughness, etc.” However, he suggests that these various modal and aspectual meanings “can all be brought under one banner: greater specification of features of the action already latent in the main verb itself or those that are compatible with it but have not yet been specified.” The light verb unfolds the “latent semantics” of the host, “characterizing the manner and implications of its performance more precisely” (Masica 1976: 143).

In a detailed description of data from the various Indo-Aryan languages of South Asia, particularly Hindi and Marathi, Hook (1974) postulates a category called ‘vector verb’, roughly equivalent to what we have called ‘light verb’. (Bahl 1967 proposes the term ‘explicator’ to refer to this class of verbs.) Of the two verbs V+V in a ‘compound verb’, the first is the host, and the second the vector or light verb. Including the less common and less productive ones, Hook catalogues 68 light verbs in Hindi (of which 24 are commonly used), as well as the various verbs that each of them accepts as its hosts.

In extensive work on complex predicate constructions with verbal hosts in Urdu, Butt (1995) lays out two constructions that she argues must be treated as complex predicate constructions, namely the permissive and the aspectual complex predicate, illustrated in (42) and (43) respectively. The sentence in (41) is the corresponding simple sentence with a single verb:

(41)
anu-ne haar banaayaa.
Anu-ERG garland made
‘Anu made a garland.’

(42)
raam-ne anu-ko haar banaane diyaa.
Ram-ERG Anu-DAT garland to make gave
‘Ram let Anu make a garland.’

(43)
anu-ne haar banaa diyaa.
Anu-ERG garland make gave
‘Anu made a garland (completely).’

The permissive construction illustrated in (42) is entirely productive. The aspectual complex predicates, however, exhibit certain interesting combinatorial restrictions. The light verb can determine the case of the subject of the clause, and must be compatible with the host in terms of whether or not the subject of the clause can be volitional. The notions of the inception and completion of an event also play a role in limiting the combinatorial possibilities (Ramchand 1997); thus, a light verb may serve to pick out or focus on the point of inception. In short, the light verb brings its own semantics and argument structure to the construction, as in the N+V complex predicates.

On the basis of evidence from patterns of agreement, control, reflexive binding, and disjoint reference, Butt demonstrates that the light verb and its host form a single syntactic predicate in (42) and (43), behaving exactly like the simple predicate in (41). On the other hand, the patterns of scrambling, negation, modification, and coordination displayed by the constructions lead to the conclusion that they need not form a single constituent in phrase structure. Butt argues that in the phrase structure of (42), the infinitival verbal host is in fact nominal, and the light verb is not a lexical category; rather, it is a Vbar, as is the combination:
In (43), on the other hand, the light verb and the host are both V0 sisters, their mother node being a Vbar:

The V+V complex predicates in Urdu, Hindi, and the other Indo-Aryan languages of South Asia raise questions about distinctions among grammatical verbs, particularly aspectual auxiliary, modal auxiliary, and light verb. In (42), the meaning is that of permission, typically found in modal auxiliary. However, as Butt argues, the construction in Urdu involves a complex predicate with a light verb which adds an argument to the clause, a property not associated with modals. Hence, we may conclude that the Hindi verb ‘give’ in (42) is a modal light verb, unlike the applicative light verb ‘give’ in Malayalam.

In (43), the verb ‘give’ adds the aspectual meaning of completion. One might ask if this grammatical verb should be treated as an aspectual light verb, or as an aspectual auxiliary in (43). It does not add an argument. However, it requires a particular argument meaning, namely that of conscious choice, of its subject. This could be used as justification for classifying it as a light verb, if it were the case that all grammatical verbs that contribute/require specific argument meanings are light verbs. However, given that modal auxiliaries – for instance, can, will, shall, and must in English – generally express meanings such as volitionality, intentionality, ability, and obligation, which belong to the same class of meanings as conscious choice, it is difficult to use this property as criterial. The only reason for treating ‘give’ in (43) as a light verb, then, is that unlike the modal auxiliaries in English, light verbs have full counterparts. One may therefore suggest that a grammatical verb is a light verb if it has a full counterpart. However, this criterion also runs into problems when faced with examples like (44) and (45):

(44)
anu us ghar-me rahtii hae.
Anu that house-in stays is
‘Anu lives/stays in that house.’

(45)
a. anu haar banaatii hae.
Anu garland makes is
‘Anu makes garlands.’
b. anu haar banaatii rahtii hae.
Anu garland make stay is
‘Anu keeps making garlands.’
c. anu haar banaa rahii hae.
Anu garland make stay is
‘Anu is making garlands.

A comparison of (44) and (45) shows that the grammatical verb rah- ‘stay/ remain/continue’ in (45b, c) has a full verb counterpart in (44). By the criterion of pairing with full verbs, therefore, rah- in (45b) and (45c) should be a light verb. However, this verb in (45c) is viewed without question as an auxiliary. We must conclude that either the treatment of rah- in (45c) as an auxiliary is not viable, or that the property of pairing with a full verb is not a sufficient condition for light verbs.

It is widely agreed that auxiliaries (including modals) and light verbs, while they need not form a single phrase structure constituent, nevertheless form a single predicate with their hosts in terms of syntactic function. Now, distinguishing between auxiliaries, light verbs, and modals, Butt and Lahiri (1998) cite as an example of a modal the following sentence with an embedded structure:

(46)
naadyaa xat likhnaa caahtii hae.
Nadya letter write-INF wish/want-IMPF is
‘Nadya wants to write a letter.’

However, it is unclear how (46) can be distinguished from a raising construction. If we take light verbs and auxiliaries (including modals) to be grammatical verbs that involve a single functional clause, the legitimacy of (46) as a modal construction is called into question. What (46) shares with modals is simply a modality meaning, which in this instance is expressed by a full verb.

A possible way to distinguish between auxiliaries and light verbs may be in terms of their contribution to the event structure of the clause: while auxiliaries participate in the modification of the event structure of their host, light verbs come with their own event structure, no matter how bleached. This is what makes a light verb a semantic predicate in its own right, allowing it to contribute arguments and argument meanings, and determine the case of arguments (Mohanan 1994; Butt 1995, 1997; Butt and Lahiri 1998). Though this is a possible move to make, it is unclear how one can in a non-ad-hoc way establish on an empirical basis the distinction between having an independent event and modifying an existing event.

subsection.heading: 6 Adjectival hosts
subsection.p: As mentioned earlier, the resultative construction in English has been treated as a complex predicate construction where the complex predicate is composed of a verb and an adjective (Simpson 1983; Jackendoff 1990b; Levin and Rappaport Hovav 1995; Hale and Keyser 1997). The construction is illustrated in (47):

(47)
a. The potter baked the clay hard.
b. The elf licked the plate clean.
c. They painted the Volkswagen purple.

While (47) illustrates complex predicates made up of a verb–adjective combination, these examples are not of interest in a discussion of light verbs, because the range of verbs that participate in the construction do not form a closed class, and therefore are not grammatical verbs.
We do, however, find true light verb constructions with adjectival hosts, such as those in (48) from Hindi:

(48)
a. kamraa saaf
huaa.
room clean became
‘The room became clean.’
b. raam-ne kamraa saaf
kiyaa.
Ram room clean did
‘Ram cleaned the room. (Ram did the room clean.)’

Compare (48a, b) with (15a, b), where the host is a noun; the meaning is only minimally different. Like N+V and V+V complex predicates, A+V complex predicates like those in (48) are entirely productive in Hindi.

The A+V complex predicates in Malayalam display an interesting twist. The language does not allow native adjectives to appear in the preverbal position in a complex predicate: adjectives, whether derived or underived (of which there are no more than a handful), must undergo nominalization to appear preverbally. Alternatively, they undergo verbalization, in which case they do not require a light verb. Yet, surprisingly, there is widespread borrowing of adjectives from English to create A+V complex predicates such as those in (49), parallel to those from Hindi in (48):

(49)
a. muri kLiin
aayi.
room clean became
‘The room became clean.’
b. raaman muri kLiin
aakki.
Raman room clean caused to become
‘Ram cleaned the room. (Ram made the room clean.)’

The borrowing of adjectives is productive; thus, the word ‘clean’ in (49a) and (49b) can be replaced by ‘tidy’, ‘neat’, ‘dirty’, ‘dark’, ‘bright’, or ‘yellow’, all with acceptable results. The A+V construction in Hindi and Malayalam reconfirms what we have observed before, namely that the light verb can determine the transitivity of the complex predicate independently of the host.

subsection.heading: 7 The ubiquitous light verb do
subsection.p: As mentioned earlier (section 4.3), Japanese and Korean have complex predicate constructions in which the light verb is ‘do’: suru in Japanese and hata in Korean. The equivalent of the verb ‘do’ appears to be one of the most pervasive light verbs across languages: kardan in Persian; kar- in the Indo-Aryan languages of South Asia, including Hindi, Gujarati, and Bengali, and gar- in Nepali; ces- in Telugu; maad- in Kannada; paNN in Tamil; and cey in Malayalam.

In all these languages, the light verb ‘do’ is completely productive, taking as its host not only native words but also words borrowed from English. An interesting quirk found in this productive complex predicate formation pattern in the South Asian languages is that typically, if the host is a native word, it is a noun; if the host is borrowed from English, it is a verb. Examples that illustrate this asymmetry are given in (50) and (51). While the illustrations are given only from two languages, the phenomenon is prevalent across the languages of the region:

(50)
Hindi
Malayalam
Gloss
a. puujaa kar puuja cey to worship
b. upkaar kar upakaaram cey to do a favor
c. madad kar sahaayam cey to help
d. tyaag kar tyaagam cey to sacrifice

(51)
Hindi
Malayalam
Gloss
a. allow kar allow cey to allow
b. edit kar edit cey to edit
c. insist kar insist cey to insist
d. wash kar wash cey to wash
In V+V complex predicates like those in (51), the borrowed English verb is incorporated into the language, with appropriate phonological adaptation.

In both Hindi and Malayalam, if the X in the X-do complex predicate is a native word, in which case X is a noun, as in (50), then the complex predicate is transitive, with an agent. If, on the other hand, the X is a borrowing from English, and hence a verb, the complex predicate may be either transitive or intransitive.
Among V+V complex predicates where the host is intransitive, Hindi and Malayalam diverge: Hindi requires that the host be unergative, while Malayalam allows both unergative and unaccusative hosts:

(52)
Hindi
Malayalam
As in the sentences:
a. jump kar jump cey The cat jumped.
b. jog jog Meg jogged.
c. *arrive arrive The train arrived.
d. *break break The teapot broke.

There is clearly a language-internal regularity visible in the phenomenon. However, the cross-linguistic details of the pattern of X+do, as well as the pattern of complex predicates of the form A+V (section 6), both of which involve words borrowed from English, appear at least for now to defy a principled account.

subsection.heading: 8 The relation between the full verb and the light verb
subsection.p: When talking about light verbs, a question that must be asked, whether or not it can be adequately answered, is: what is the relation between a lexical verb and its grammatical counterpart? Although the semantic and syntactic properties of a light verb are not identical to those of its full independent counterpart, there is clearly a systematic synchronic relation between the two. Thus, all analyses of complex predicates acknowledge that there is something light or incomplete about the light verb in relation to the full verb. Yet some central aspect of the syntax and semantics of the full verb is typically preserved in the light verb, whether it be valency, argument meanings, or case assignment. How, then, are the two verbs related? How must the relatedness be expressed by linguistic theory?

One of the explanations for the relation between full and light verbs has been in terms of the historical perspective. Historically, when a lexical form undergoes grammaticalization to become a grammatical form, the change is often manifested as a cline. (See Hopper and Traugott 1993: 103–113 for a detailed discussion of clines, and caveats.) A very general grammaticalization cline suggested for verbs is the following: full verb > auxiliary > clitic > affix. (See Bybee 1985; Bybee and Dahl 1989, for studies of cross-linguistic verbal clines, and Lord 1976 for similar grammaticalization patterns.) On this cline of grammaticalization, one of the intermediate stages between the full verb and the auxiliary is represented by Hook's (1974) vector verb (Hopper and Traugott 1993). The large and variable repertoire of light verbs listed in the various Indo-Aryan languages of South Asia, as well as the restrictions on the semantic classes of verbs each of them accepts as its host, suggest a need to treat them as a class distinct from auxiliaries, closer to the full verbs.

Butt and Lahiri (1998), however, argue that light verbs do not belong on the grammaticalization cline mentioned above. The reasons they provide on the basis of light verbs in Urdu and Bengali are the following. First, V+V as well as N+V complex predicates have been around for at least two thousand years, and though absent in Vedic, are found in Classical Sanskrit texts, as well as in Prakrit and Pali. Interestingly, the structural ambiguity between a participial reading and a complex predicate reading found in Sanskrit is found in the complex predicate constructions in the Urdu, Bengali, and Hindi of today.

Second, while old participle forms have grammaticalized to affixes in the tense–aspect system, light verbs have remained intact. Furthermore, they interact with all the tenses and aspects, rather than forming a subclass within the system.

Finally, it is interesting to note that the basic set of verbs that appear as light verbs display a striking resemblance across languages. The languages, many of them genetically and areally unrelated to one another, range from Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Persian, and the various language families of South Asia, including Indic (Hindi, Bengali, Marathi, Sinhala), Dravidian (Malayalam, Tamil, Telugu), Tibeto-Burman, and Munda, to Amerind languages like Tepehua, African languages like Yoruba, and creoles like Sranan. The verbs that have light counterparts are typically selected from a set that includes ‘do’, ‘become’, ‘have’, ‘make’, ‘come’, ‘go’, ‘move’, ‘give’, ‘take’, ‘put’, ‘throw’, ‘release’, ‘fall’, ‘rise’, ‘hit’, and ‘strike’. What these verbs appear to have in common is that they are the semantically simplest verbs in any language (Grimshaw 1997b). They are relatively unspecified for information, other than, for instance, movement and directionality. This absence of semantic specification renders them amenable to service in a variety of constructions (Butt and Lahiri 1998).

This brings us back to our question: how do we express the relation between the full verb and the light verb in syntactic theory? Butt and Lahiri suggest two possibilities. One is to assume that, for every verb that has a full as well as a light manifestation, there are two lexical entries: one with specification of the full verb, and the other for the light verb. The other is to postulate a single underspecified representation for each verb, which lends itself to use either as a full verb or as a light verb, depending on what is required by the larger context of the clause. Butt and Lahiri favor the latter as the more plausible assumption.

Whatever the formal solution (e.g., full specification, underspecification, or deletion of specification), the substantive challenge at the level of grammar is that of stating the general laws (rules or constraints) that relate light verbs and their full counterparts. The challenge at the level of Universal Grammar is that of capturing the cross-linguistically recurring patterns in such laws, not available at the current stage in linguistic theory.

subsection.heading: 9 Theoretical Issues and problems of analysis
9.1 Variety of structure in complex predicates
subsection.p: As we have seen, complex predicate constructions involving light verbs display a confusing array of structures and properties. First, the host of a light verb can be a verb, noun, or adjective. Some languages allow all three types of hosts.

In terms of the parameters of variation with respect to phrase structure, we have seen that a light verb, its host, and the entire complex predicate may be either a lexical category or a phrasal category. In N+V complex predicates in Hindi, the host is a lexical category (section 4.2), while in the parallel N+V complex predicates in Malayalam, the host is a phrasal category (Mohanan 1983). The light verb in N+V complex predicates in Hindi is a phrasal category (section 4.2), while that in the causative predicate in Catalan is a lexical category (Alsina 1997). Like the N+V (section 4.2) and V+V (section 5.3) complex predicates in Hindi, the entire causative predicate in Catalan must be treated as a phrasal category, but in Chichewa, it is a lexical category (Alsina 1997).

We have also found that in addition to being a predicate, and part of a complex predicate, a nominal host can also be an argument of the light verb. Hindi has two types of N+V complex predicates, the difference between them being precisely that the host is an argument of the light verb in one type but not in the other.

subsection.heading: 9.2 Diversity in analysis
subsection.p: In addition to the clear cases of the language-internal and cross-linguistic variability in the structure of complex predicates, we also find considerable divergence in the claims that have been made on complex predicates and light verbs in various languages. It is unclear at this point if the diversity of claims is a reflection of further cross-linguistic variability of the construction, or if it is a function of differences in analyses whose empirical claims need to be tested. Wherever the latter is the case, it is important to look for empirical evidence to choose from among the analyses.

Most treatments of complex predicates involve the combination of two semantic predicates into a single syntactic predicate. A brief look at the diversity of analyses of complex predicates available in the literature reveals four classes of issues.

subsection.heading: 9.2.1 ‘Movement’ and ‘restructuring’ vs. multidimensionality
subsection.p: The first issue has to do with the problem of expressing how a light verb and its host behave like a single syntactic predicate with respect to functional structure, even though they may be two independent units with respect to categorial structure. This problem has two solutions (section 4.1). One solution involves a syntactic transformation of one representation into another. For instance, in an analysis of N+V complex predicates in English, Chomsky (1975b) employs restructuring to transform the categorially motivated structure [[make] [the claim that . . . ]] (10a) to the functionally motivated structure [[make the claim] [that . . . ]] (10b). The same need for reanalysis, or ‘restructuring’, appears in V+V complex predicates as well. Variants of the transformational approach are employed in the treatments of complex predicates in GB, including movement in Logical Form (Baker 1988a; Jayaseelan 1988; Speas 1990; Huang 1992a; Chomsky 1995b; Cinque 1997a, 1997b). These approaches share with Relational Grammar the essential idea of ‘clause union’, or the hypothesis that such phenomena involve the reduction of a bi-clausal structure into a monoclausal one (Aissen and Perlmutter 1976, 1983).

The alternative solution involves two parallel linked representations. Within this approach, one structure is categorial (13a), as in the first solution, but the other is functional (13b); the two structures are related through principles of correspondence rather than the procedure of transformations. This is the strategy adopted, for instance, in the LFG-inspired treatments of complex predicates (Alsina 1992, 1996; Mohanan 1994, 1997; Butt 1995, 1997; Matsumoto 1996a; among others).

The choice between these approaches to the mismatch between functional and categorial information derives from the commitments of the particular model or framework that the individual linguist employs, and is particularly difficult (though not impossible) to test on empirical grounds. We will not pursue this issue here.

subsection.heading: 9.2.2 How empty are light verbs?
subsection.p: The second issue is that of expressing the contributions to the complex predicate by the light verb and by the host. Some approaches, such as that of Grimshaw and Mester (1988), assume that the light verb has no syntactic or semantic information to contribute, and that the relevant requirements of the host are projected up to the complex predicate. This assumption is clearly untenable in the light of the range of phenomena that we have reviewed so far, whether the host is nominal, verbal, or adjectival. Other approaches (Alsina 1992, 1996; Mohanan 1994, 1997; Butt 1995, 1997; Matsumoto 1996a; among others) assume, on the basts of large bodies of evidence, that both the light verb and its host can make a contribution to the complex predicate. The light verb can even contribute meanings to the complex predicate not found in the full verb (section 5.2).

subsection.heading: 9.2.3 Complex predicate formation: event structure or argument structure?
subsection.p: The third issue concerns the representation of the information contributed independently by the light verb and the host. In frameworks that make use of theta-role labels of the traditional sort, valency information is conflated with the semantics of the arguments. As demonstrated by the phenomena we have reviewed in applicatives in Malayalam (section 5.2), valency must necessarily be factored apart from argument meanings: a light verb can require the addition of an argument meaning, which can be satisfied either by merging the meaning with an existing argument, or by adding a new argument.

The V+V complex predicates (section 5.3) also raise questions about argument structure. Given that a complex predicate has two semantic predicates and one syntactic (functional) predicate, how do we articulate the relation between the semantics and the syntax? In other words, how do two semantic predicates merge as a single syntactic predicate?

Differences among analyses in terms of this question crucially hinge on differences in the conception of the level of argument structure, the issue having to do with the representation of thematic role information. On the one hand, works like Rosen (1989), Grimshaw (1990), and Mohanan (1994) argue for a skeletal argument structure that represents valency and argument hierarchy information, without any semantic content. Butt (1995), on the other hand, incorporates semantic information at the level of argument structure, adopting Jackendoff's (1990b) Lexical Conceptual Structure representations directly into argument structure. Alsina's (1996) argument structure is less elaborated than that in Butt, but richer than the skeletal argument structure in that it includes proto-role information (Dowty 1991).

Given these differences, variants of at least two possible views of complex predicate formation emerge, yielding two types of analyses. In one type, Alsina (1996), for complex predicates in the Bantu languages and in Romance, and Butt (1995), for V+V complex predicates in Urdu, formulate complex predicate formation in terms of the correspondence of two argument structures and a single functional structure. In other words, each of the two semantic predicates has its own argument structure, with an embedded a-structure representation.

Mohanan (1994), in contrast, formulates N+V complex predicate formation in Hindi as a correspondence of two semantic structures and a single argument structure. The crucial difference between the two approaches is that the complex a-structure hypothesis implies the possibility of two logical subjects (highest argument in a minimal a-structure) in a single functional clause, while the simple a-structure hypothesis entails a single logical subject. In Hindi, evidence on the basis of which to choose between the two comes from facts of reflexive binding, which is sensitive to logical subjecthood: a reflexive in this language takes as its antecedent either a grammatical subject or a logical subject. It is extremely difficult to find examples of complex predicates in which, given a compositional argument structure, the logical subjects of the embedded predicate and the matrix predicate would be distinct. However, in the rare examples that can be found among N+V complex predicates, only one of them can bind the reflexive. This points to a representation with a single argument structure without embedding (Mohanan 1994). The hypothesis of dual logical subjects is therefore untenable at least for the N+V complex predicates in Hindi. Whether this is true of the V+V complex predicates in the literature remains to be seen.

In the absence of relevant evidence, we may entertain a parametric choice between simple and complex argument structures available to languages in complex predicate formation. How do we decide which choice is appropriate in a particular instance? What is the kind of empirical evidence, such as that described above from reflexive binding in Hindi, that would allow for the choice between the alternative analyses? Or are they empirically equivalent variants, resulting from minor individual differences in the conception of the organization of grammar? These are questions for future research.

subsection.heading: 10 Conclusion
subsection.p: We hope that it is clear that research since the early 1980s, whether descriptive or theoretical, and regardless of specific frameworks, has contributed considerably to our understanding of the phenomenon of complex predicates and their formation. While unanswered questions abound, the wealth of data keeps growing.
In the preceding sections, we have addressed the questions outlined at the beginning of the chapter, here briefly summarized:

li.p: How can we characterize the complex predicate construction in such a way that it can be distinguished from other constructions involving grammatical elements?
How can we characterize the light verb construction as a special case of complex predicates, to be distinguished from other types of complex predicates?
How do complex predicates vary, and what are the limits of their variability?
